loans.name: Marcy

texts.en: Marcy B., age 35, is widowed and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Marcy owns and operates a sari-sari (variety retail shop) selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and toothpaste in her community. She also buys and sells firewood. They are from the village of Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro City. Marcy has been in her business for over five years and earns approximately 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Marcy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marcy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Marcy is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like snack foods and canned goods. This will be her seventh loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like snack foods and canned goods

In 2007, Lydia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be her third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. S. sells groceries and snacks, earning $5 US per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning $3 US per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend $30 US on food and $45 US on other expenses. S. is requesting a loan of $400 US to hire people to help harvest her rice. In the future, she would like to use additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

She also buys and sells firewood, while her husband has a welding shop. Jesusisa is a 59-year-old married woman from the village of Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro City. She has been in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 9,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Jesusisa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Jesusisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 16,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. Jesusisa is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products like bananas and vegetables. This will be her sixth loan from HSPFI. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. texts.en:
Sou K., 32, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. K. is a tailor and sells groceries, earning an income of $6 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. 

Each month, the family has to spend $35 on food and $40 on the other necessary expenses. 

K. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more groceries to stock her store. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Crispina

texts.en:
Crispina R. is from the village of Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 42 years old. Crispina is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Crispina owns & operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling ready to wear clothing & shoe products from NATASHA & AVON in the local community. Crispina has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Crispina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Crispina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Crispina is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like t-shirts & blouses. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Crispina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell like t-shirts & blouses.

location.town: Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Marife

texts.en:
Marife is a married woman who lives in Naga City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating a fish vending business. Her husband Ermesito, who is 41 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have nine children, between the ages of 2 and 21 years old. 

Marife joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 7 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marife has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 17,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 28,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 8th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, with which she intends to buy fresh fish to sell at a market so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Marife is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund the operations of her fish vending.

loans.name: Alventina

texts.en:
Alventina S. is from the village of Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 53 years old. Alventina is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Alventina owns & operates a business making & selling Filipino snacks & other delicacies like biko, suman, puto or rice cake & bibingka in the local community. Alventina has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alventina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Alventina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional ingredients & working capital. Alventina is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like flour, eggs & rice for rice cakes. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Alventina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed, such as flour, eggs & rice for rice cakes.

location.town: Consolacion, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Ryan Vennyl

texts.en:
Ryan Vennyl G. is from the city of Baybay Ozamiz City. He is 32 years old. Ryan Vennyl is married. To make a living, Ryan Vennyl owns & operates a business primarily operating a motor transport services. Ryan Vennyl has been engaged in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Ryan Vennyl joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Ryan Vennyl has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from GDMPC. Ryan Vennyl is requesting a new loan of 25000 PHP which will be used to repair existing vehicle for better service. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Ryan Vennyl from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Yarn

texts.en: Yarn S., 33, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. S. sells clothes, earning an income of USD 7 per day. Her husband is a driver, earning an income of USD 15 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 35 on food and USD 17 on the other necessary expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more clothes to resell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Terisita

texts.en: Terisita is 56 years old and married. She supports her family by operating three business ventures: a general store, videoke and computer games, and raising livestock. She lives in Brgy. Jaguimit, Naga, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 15,600 Philippines pesos (PHP). Terisita is borrowing PHP 25,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 22,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Terisita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.name: Badamragchaa

texts.en:
Badamragchaa is 28 years old and lives with her husband and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent. Her husband is an overseer for a local company and her son attends kindergarten. Badamragchaa supports her family by operating a clothing retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia.

In 2005, when she first began her business, she rented a stall at Narantuul from another person who had a rental contract with Narantuul. This was an unstable business situation for her because the middleman could dismiss her at any time. Usually, it is very difficult to obtain a rental contract with Narantuul because the stalls are in such high demand. 

However, in 2007, Badamragchaa had the opportunity to sign a rental contract directly with Narantuul to make her business more stable. Also, she bought land with 2.5 million MNT of her business earnings in 2008. 

Now, her working capital is 2 million MNT and she sells a lot of seasonal kids' clothing. She is requesting a 1 million MNT to purchase kids' clothes for spring from Ereen City, China. She wants to use this loan to help support her in this very busy shopping season of the year.

Her current home changes temperatures very quickly, according to the outside conditions. So her family wants to build a new house with her business earnings in 2011.

loans.use: To purchase kids' clothes for spring

loans.name: Odbaatar

texts.en:
Odbaatar is 40 years old and lives with his wife, daughter and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. His family lives in a small house in the outer ger districts of the city. Both his children attend secondary school. Odbaatar supports his family by operating a clothing retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia, with regular help from his wife. 

In 1995, when he first began his business, his working capital was 500,000 MNT and now his stall has 3 million MNT in working capital. In 2003, his family bought a small house and in 2009, he bought a used car with his business earnings. 

He wants to expand his business by buying his own clothing shop. With this loan, Odbaatar will purchase clothes for spring from Ereen City, China. He wants to use this loan to help support him in this very busy shopping season of the year.

Odbaatar also said, "It's my personal goal to support my children's education and to let them have a safe life in the future, so they can live happily."

loans.name: Ranjana

texts.en:
This is 33-year-old Ranjana P.. She is married and has 2 children aged 14 and 10. In 2010, she established her grocery store. Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to buy grocery goods for her shop. In the future, Ranjana plans to lift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

In the Kathmandu Valley, the small grocery stores, called pasals, are an important part of the local economy. Fresh produce, milk, and staples such as rice, lentils and flour are purchased daily for cooking in the home. Owners of small grocery stores use Kiva loans to increase their purchasing power and profit margins. By keeping inventory strong and purchasing in larger amounts, owners of these small stores are able to increase profitability. While a typical pasal might be no more than 100 sq. feet, they are always full of bargaining customers, incoming produce and shrewd businesswomen. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007. Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community. For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:
 BPW Partner Page     Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team"

loans.name: Anju

texts.en:
This is 54-year-old Anju T.. She is married and has 3 children aged 30, 26 and 25. In 2000, she established her vegetable farming business. Working 7 days a week and 6 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 1 loan from Patan BPW. She used her most recent loan to buys seeds and fertilizers for vegetable farming. In the future, Anju plans to lift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.   

Over 70% of Nepal's economy is agricultural. Typically, Nepali households grow crops on small plots of terraced land. Rice (bhat), lentils (daal) and vegetables (thakari) are the staples of the Nepali diet. With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to purchase greater amounts of seed and fertilizer.  With more seeds and fertilizer, a borrower is able to grow cash crops to be sold at the local market. Such crops allow households to move beyond subsistence and provide much-needed cash income throughout the year.  

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:
 BPW Partner Page     Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team.

loans.name: Flamboyan Group

texts.en: Flamboyan Group received a new loan on January 18, 2011 with the number of loans per member amounting to 1.4 million Indonesian rupiah (IDR). With the same purpose as the previous period, this loan will be used to buy pigs and feed. Although not all members can have a good business, the spirit of the members remains high. Some members suffered losses because pigs get sick and die even with treatment. With the realization of the loan, branch chief KSU MUK shed some light on pig farming – it is good and right. It is intended that members are reminded every time, so they can raise pigs properly and losses due to mortality can be reduced. KSU MUK is not only an institution that lends money, but is also responsible for the success of business borrowers. Information about Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK) This loan is being serviced by Koperasi Mitra Usaha Kecil (MUK), a microfinance institution headquartered in Bali Indonesia. MUK follows a cooperative model offering microenterprise development services to its clients, including microloans, savings programs, and business consultation services to help small business owners and their families improve their everyday lives. MUK envisions a prosperous world free from poverty. It is dedicated to raising society’s awareness of environmental issues and to providing opportunities for people in chronic poverty to improve their lives. MUK provides services to all lower income people throughout Bali without consideration of race, religion or culture. Mitra Usaha Kecil is dedicated to empowering people, creating jobs, stimulating small businesses and strengthening communities. For more information about MUK, please visit our Kiva partner page and website. Also, consider supporting MUK and its borrowers by joining our Kiva lending team Friends of Mitra Usaha Kecil. .

loans.use: To buy pigs and feed

loans.name: Kavita

texts.en:
This is 30-year-old Kavita A.. She is married and has 2 children aged 10 and 8. In 2000, she established her cow raising business.  Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family. She has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent one to buy a young milk cow. In the future, Kavita plans to lift the economic condition of her family. She thanks you for your support.

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal. Cows are never raised for beef but for their milk from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made. Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking. On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day. At the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50. In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks. The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:

texts.en:
Jenelyn is 23 years old, single and supports her family by operating 2 business ventures: a general store and a firewood & charcoal sales business. She lives in Talisay City, Cebu. Jenelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 9 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jenelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, lifting the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use to buy stock for the general store so that she can continue to save up for the future improvement of her business. Jenelyn is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. loans.name: Radha

texts.en:
This is 45-year-old Radha T..  She is married and has three children aged 25, 22 and 21.  In 2004, she established her cow-raising business.  Working 7 days a week and 4 hours a day, she supports her family.  She has already received and successfully repaid five loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent loan to buy a young dairy cow.  In the future, Radha plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

Dairy cows are an important source of nutrition and income in Nepal.  Cows are never raised for beef, but for their milk from which curd (duy) and fresh cheese (paneer) are made.  Jersey cows are the preferred breed for milking.  On average, a dairy cow in Nepal will produce about 10 liters of milk each day.  In the local market, a liter of milk sells for about USD $0.50.  In addition to producing milk, cows provide dung that is used in home construction, as fuel for fires, and can be captured in methane storage tanks.  The purchase of a dairy cow, made possible through a Kiva loan, is an investment that will repay itself many times over.  

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Katmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women. In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates.

loans.use: To buy a young dairy cow

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Long T., 46, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. T. sells food, earning an income of USD 2.36 per day. One of her children sells car spare parts, earning an income of USD 3 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 80 on food and USD 34 on the other necessary expenses. T. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a truck to transport vegetables to sell. In the future, she would like to use the additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a truck to transport vegetables to sell

loans.name: Anselma

texts.en: Anselma is a married woman who lives in Talisay City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating one business venture: fruits and vegetables vending. Her husband, Michael, who is 35 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have six children who are between 1 and 12 years old. Four of their children are currently going to school. Anselma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Anselma has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 20,000, which she intends to use to buy fruits to sell to a market so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children and expansion of her business. Anselma is a Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable) woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team: http://www.kiva.org/team/nwtf_philippines

loans.use: To fund the operations of her fruits and vegetables business

loans.name: Justina

texts.en:
Justina S. is from the village of Alegria, Aurora Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 54 years old. Justina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Justina owns & operates a business planting & harvesting corn for sale. Justina has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Justina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Justina has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Justina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Justina from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

She will use the rest of the loan towards purchasing farm supplies to use on her field.

They have seven children, two of whom are single and five are married and living in their own house.

She faces a difficult season if she is not able to irrigate her crop. Sem P. is taking out her loan to purchase some pipe and a water pump for her crops. With any remainder of the loan funds, she will  build a new toilet for the whole family.

Or R. would like to take out a loan of $1,000 to purchase more ducks to breed and also to purchase feed for the ducks.

loans.name: Van

loans.name: Otgon

texts.en:
Otgon is 39 years old and lives with her mother, husband and two daughters in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a small house in the outer districts of the city. Her older daughter attends primary school and her younger daughter is 3 years old and stays at home with Otgon's mother. 
 
Otgon supports her family by operating two clothing retail stalls at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia. She has regular help from her husband who usually goes to Ereen City in China, where he buys the clothes and brings them back. 

In 1996, when she began her business, she sold her handmade suits at Denjiin Thousand, the first largest outdoor market in Mongolia. Before this, she was a seamstress for a local sewing factory. 

Now, her business has grown and her working capital is five million MNT. Otgon sells clothes imported from Ereen as well as her handmade clothes in her two stalls at Narantuul. In the winter, she sews coats to sell and purchases shirts to sell from Ereen. With this loan, she will purchase materials for her handmade coats and a wider variety of clothing from Ereen. 

Her goal is to grow her business with this loan and be able to buy her own sewing factory in order to expand her country’s employment.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her handmade coats and a wider variety of clothing to sell

Roun S. would like to take out a loan of $500 to purchase more electrical tools for his business. He would use the rest of the loan to invest in his wife's business, selling fish.

loans.name: Ernalein

texts.en:
Ernalein G. is from the village of Looc, Catarman, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Ernalein is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $276 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ernalein joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. 

Ernalein is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like snack foods and canned goods. This will be her 7th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to expand the  business. 

About HSPFI:

loans.name: Togoo

texts.en:
Togoo is 48 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her family lives in a ger, a traditional Mongolian felt tent, in the outer ger districts of the city. Her husband is a driver and he drives a taxi. Her daughter is an assistant singer at a local theater. Togoo thinks her daughter will be a good singer in the future.  

Togoo supports her family by operating a clothing retail stall at Narantuul, the largest outdoor market in Mongolia.  

 In 1997, her family moved to Ulaanbaatar from the countryside. At this time, when she began her business, she sold her handmade coats to Narantuul market’s retailers, because she didn’t have her own clothing retail stall. 

In 1999, she bought her stall with 1 million MNT from her business earnings. From this, her business has grown because she can sell directly to customers. Then, in 2007, her family bought land with 2.5 million MNT and in 2009, her family bought a car with 6 million MNT with her business earnings.  

Now, her working capital is about 2 million MNT. Togoo sells her handmade kid’s outfits and other clothes in her stall at Narantuul. In winter, she usually sews children's outfits and coats. With this loan, she will purchase materials for her handmade coats and outfits.

Her goal is to grow her business with this loan and be able to buy her own sewing factory and build her own house.

loans.use: To purchase materials for her hand made coats and outfits

texts.en:
Mrs. Soeurn L. has spent her life cultivating crops. This is a skill she learned from her grandparents when she was young. Mrs. Soeurn L. is married and has four kids; three are single, and one is married, and has started a new home. Two of her children always share their gross income with her, working as construction workers in the province of Kompong Cham. Her husband works in the farm fields frequentL. alongside her. 

Mrs. Soeurn L. is able to plant crops at least twice a year by making use of both rainy and dry seasons. PresentL., she would like to do dry-season rice fields, but Mrs. Soeurn L. doesn’t have capital to do so. So, Mrs. Soeurn L. is looking for a loan to use towards purchasing a piece of farmland, fertilizers, and seeds for planting.

loans.name: Marla

texts.en:
Marla N. is a married woman who lives in Dumaguete City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a Pedicab (bicycle rickshaw) business. 

Her husband, Reynaldo N., who is 35 years old, works as a painter to earn his living. They have one child who is 12 years old. 

Marla joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Marla has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 27,500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her sixth cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 10,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell and for additional capital for the business, so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her child. 

Marla is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable"). NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon, a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell
