Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Kamissa

texts.fr:
Madame Kamissa C. est une femme âgée de 32 ans qui vit avec ses 4 enfants et son époux dans une famille nucléaire à N’Tentou, un des quartiers de la ville de Ouelessebougou, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro(deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Kamissa n’a pas eu la chance de fréquenter l’école  pour des raisons familiales,  alors très tôt elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat vente d’articles divers  tels les habits, les pochettes, les chaussures, les parures, les condiments alimentaires, etc. 
Après avoir correctement remboursé le  premier prêt, Kamissa est à son deuxième prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, quelques douzaines d’habits pour enfants et 50 paires de chaussures de différentes sortes, auprès des grossistes du marché de Ouelessebougou. Elle effectue sa vente à la maison, au  marché de Ouelesseboubou et en ambulant dans les différents quartiers de la ville, en détail, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Madame Kamissa C. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, aider le mari à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités. 
Kamissa ambitionne diversifier davantage ses activités et devenir grossiste en habillements et chaussures à Ouelessebougou
texts.en:
Mrs. Kamissa C. is a 32-year old woman who lives with her 4 children and her husband in a nuclear family in N'Tentou. It is a quarter in the city of Ouelessebougou, a prefecture of Kati in the region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

Kamissa did not have the chance to go to school for family circumstances. Therefore she became   interested in revenue generating activities since she was very young, especially the buying and   selling of various merchandise, such as clothing, purses, shoes, jewelry, condiments, etc.

After she successfully repaid her first loan, Kamissa is requesting a second individual loan.   She plans on using it to purchase a few dozen pieces of children's clothing and 50 pairs of various types of shoes from a wholesaler in the market in Ouelessebougou. She carries out her sales from her house, in the market in Ouelessebougou, an itinerantly to the various quarters of the city. Her business is a retail business and she completes her sales in cash and credit, to a clientele made up of women and men. 

Mrs. Kamissa C. expects to earn a monthly income of 40.000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan, to help her husband meet the household expenses, and the remaining part will be reinvested into the business. 

Kamissa endeavors to further diversify her business and to become a clothing and shoe wholesaler in Ouelessebougou.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with eight children, six of whom attend school while two have graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For over twenty years, she has operated a food selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Fatuma faces a major challenge of price fluctuations in her business, the price of foodstuffs being so high. She hopes to renovate her workplace and sell a variety of foods in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business. With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase juice, yogurt, beans, etc.

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
Monsieur Salif D.  est un homme  qui est âgé de 40 ans et qui vit avec ses 4 enfants et son épouse dans une famille traditionnelle dans la ville de Ouelessebougou, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Afin de s’insérer dans le  tissu économique, Salif,  qui est enseignant de formation entreprena plusieurs activités mais sans succès. Alors il commença  à apprendre auprès de son frère, le commerce d’articles divers avant d’opter finalement pour le stockage commercialement des articles tels les céréales, le charbon de bois, les produits de cueillettes tels le néré, les noix d’acajou et sur commande des fruits et légumes tels les pastèques, les courges etc.  
Nanti  de 5 années d’expériences dans le domaine, il est très sollicité.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, Salif décide d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Salif  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 1 tonne de maïs, 500 kg d’arachide et 4 sacs de niébé, auprès des paysans producteurs de Famana, Keleya et Ouroun qu’il stockera pendant au moins 2 mois. Il effectue sa vente au marché de Ouelesseboubou, au comptant et rarement à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Salif D. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Salif D. is a 40-year old man who lives with his 4 children and his wife in a traditional family in the city of Ouelessebougou, a prefecture of Kati in the region of Koulikoro. 

In order to integrate himself into the local economy, Salif, a teacher by training, set out in various businesses without success. So he learned from his brother the business of selling a variety of merchandise before finally opting to start selling articles such as cereal grains, charcoal, harvest products, including nere nuts, cashews, and on order, fruits and vegetables such as watermelons and squash etc.

Benefiting from 5 years' experience in the field, he is high sought out. 

In his search for additional financial resources, Salif decided to join the credit program at the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). It is his first individual loan. 

Salif plans on using his loan to purchase 1 ton of corn, 500 kg of peanuts and 4 sacks of cowpeas from the producers of Famana, Keleya and Ouroun. He will stock his inventory for at least 2 months. He carries out his sales in the Ouelessebougou market in cash and rarely on credit, to a clientele made up of women and men. 

Salif D. expects to make a monthly income of 25.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to provide for the family's expenses and to reinvest the remaining portion into the business.

loans.use: To purchase cereal grains.

loans.name: Waraba

texts.fr:
Madame Waraba D. est une femme âgée de 29 ans qui vit avec ses 7 enfants et son époux dans une famille nucléaire à N’Tentou, un des quartiers de la ville de Ouelessebougou, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Waraba n’a pas eu la chance d’aller à l’école,  alors très tôt elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat et à la vente d’habits et de condiments alimentaires.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les deux premiers prêts, Waraba est à son troisième prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, des douzaines d’habits pour enfants et pour femmes, auprès des grossistes à Bamako et quelques fois au marché de Ouelessebougou auprès de forains. Elle effectue sa vente à la maison et aux marchés de Ouelesseboubou, Tièlé, Sido et Sélingué, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Madame Waraba D. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, aider le mari à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités. 
Waraba ambitionne diversifier davantage ses activités et devenir grossiste  en habillements pour enfants à Ouelessebougou
texts.en:
Mrs. Waraba D. is a 29-year old woman who lives with her 7 children and her husband in a nuclear family in N'Tentou, a quarter in the city of Ouelessebougou, of the Kati prefecture, in the Region of Koulikoro. 

Waraba did not have the opportunity to go to school, so at a very young age she became interested in revenue-generating activities, notably the buying and selling of clothing and condiments.  After she successfully repaid the first two loans, Waraba is on her third individual loan. She will use it to purchase dozens of articles of children's and ladies’ clothing from the wholesalers in Bamako and, on occasion, in the Ouelessebougou market fairgrounds. She carries out her sales from her house and in the markets of Ouelessebougou, in Tiele, Sido, and Selingue, completing her sales in cash and credit to a clientele made up of women and men. 

Waraba D. expects to earn a monthly income of 40.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to support her husband in meeting the family's expenses, and to reinvest the remaining portion in the business. 

Waraba endeavors to further diversify her business and to become a children's clothing wholesaler in Ouelessebougou.

loans.use: To purchase clothing for resale.

loans.name: Memunatu

texts.en: This is 33-year-old Memunatu. She is married and has one child who is five years old. In 2007, Memunatu established her used clothing business. She began her business because she wanted to make income.  Working six days a week and eight hours a day, she earns about Le 1,300,000 every month. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 5,000,000 in order to buy used clothing. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 1,300,000. In the future, Memunatu plans to build a shop for herself and educate her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more used clothing

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Monsieur Moussa Samaké  est âgé de 25 ans et vit avec ses 2 enfants et son épouse dans une famille traditionnelle à Moridjambougou, un des quartiers de la ville de Ouelessebougou, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Moussa Samaké n’a pas eu la chance  de réussir à l’école car il fut  vite exclu du système éducatif.  Alors il s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment  à l’embouche (qui est une des activités de leur famille) et à l’achat stockage vente de céréales qu’il appris auprès de son oncle. Avec une expérience de quatre ans, Monsieur Moussa Samaké jouit d’une grande renommée et est très sollicité à Ouelessebougou et environs.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt il est à son deuxième individuel  qui servira à acheter, 4 tonnes de céréales (maïs, haricot, mil) auprès des paysans producteurs qu’il gardera pendant au moins un mois. Il vend  essentiellement en gros à une clientèle constituée de revendeurs venant des grandes villes telles Bamako.
Moussa Samaké espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et  être réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Moussa Samake is 25 years old and he lives with his 2 children and his wife in a traditional family in Moridjambougou, a quarter in the city of Ouelessebougou of the Kati prefecture, in the Region of Koulikoro. 

Moussa Samake did not have the chance to complete school and early on he left the school system.   He became interested in revenue-generating activities, especially raising livestock (one of the family businesses) and the sale of cereal grains, a business he learned from his uncle. With a four-year experience, Mr. Moussa Samake enjoys a high reputation and is highly solicited in Ouelessebougou and the surrounding regions.

In order to satisfy his growing clientele, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). Having successfully repaid his first loan, he is now on his second individual loan. It will be used to purchase 4 tons of cereal grains (corn, beans, millet) from the producers. He will store his inventory for at least one month. He sells essentially in wholesale to a clientele made up of retailers who come from large cities, such as Bamako. 

Moussa Samake expects to earn a monthly income of 25.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan and to reinvest the remaining portion in his business.

loans.use: To purchase cereal grains.

loans.name: Sabine

texts.fr:
Âgée de 55 ans, Madame Sabine Dembélé vit avec ses coépouses, ses beaux frères, belles sœurs, beaux parents et leurs 6 enfants dans  la famille de leur feu époux  à Keleya, un des chefs lieu de commune rurale de la préfecture de Bougouni, troisième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Sabine est matrone de son état, exerçant au Centre de Santé Communautaire de Keleya.  En plus de cette activité professionnelle, elle excelle dans l’achat vente d’articles divers tels les matériels en plastique (tasses, glacières, assiettes, louches etc.)
Sabine a une grande expérience de ce secteur et elle est très appréciée et sollicitée à Keleya et environs. Elle est à son premier individuel avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Sabine  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 2 douzaines de glacières de différentes dimensions et quelques de louches et d’assiettes.
Elle s’approvisionne  au Burkina Faso et effectue sa vente aux marchés de Keleya et de Sido les jours de foires, essentiellement en espèce et en détail à une clientèle diverse et variée.
Madame Sabine Dembélé compte réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 100.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, contribuer aux dépenses de la famille élargie et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Fifty-five year-old Mrs. Sabine Dembele lives with the co-wives, her brothers-in-law, her sisters-in-law, and her parents-in-law and with the 6 children of their late husband in Keleya, one of the larger rural communities in the Bougouni prefecture, third administrative region in the Republic of Mali. 

Sabine is a matron, practicing at the Community Health Centre in Keleya. In addition to this professional activity, she also sells a variety of plastic merchandise (cups, plates, ladles etc.)

Sabine has a great deal of experience in the sector and she is very well liked and solicited in Keleya and neighboring regions.  She is on her first individual loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). Sabine plans on using her loan to purchase 2 dozen coolers of various sizes and some ladles and plates.

She makes her purchases in Burkina Faso and carries out her sales in the markets in Keleya and Sido on fair days, usually in cash and on credit to a diverse and varied clientele. 

Mrs. Sabine Dembele expects to earn a monthly income of 100.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to contribute towards the expenses of their extended family, and to reinvest in the business.

loans.use: To purchase plastic merchandise.

loans.name: Sibiri

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Sibiri C.  est âgé de 57 ans et vit avec ses 13 enfants et son épouse dans une famille monogame à Banankoro, un des villages de la préfecture de Kati, relevant de Koulikoro (deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Enseignant de son état à l’école fondamentale de Banankoro, Sibiri C.,  afin de subvenir aux charges de sa famille nombreuse, est  devenu le promoteur d’un restaurant depuis maintenant  5 ans. Il jouit d’une forte renommée et réputation auprès de la population locale et des routiers. Sibiri est à son deuxième prêt individuel avec Soro Yiriwaso, le premier ayant été remboursé sans aucune difficulté. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse et exigeante, Sibiri décida de continuer à collaborer avec l’institution. 
Il compte utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour acheter, 2 tonnes de riz et quelques colis de condiments alimentaires en gros  à Bamako (capitale du Mali). Il vend ses plats alimentaires (riz au gras, riz à la sauce arachide, tomate et aux feuilles vertes) dans son restaurant sis au marché se trouvant aux abords de la route internationale reliant Bamako à Abidjan, essentiellement  au comptant et à crédit payable mensuellement pour les fonctionnaires de la localité.
Sibiri C. envisage réaliser avec ce prêt, un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 70.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt,  subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et le reste  réinvestir dans les activités.
texts.en:
Sibiri C. is 57 years old and he lives with his 13 children and his wife in a monogamous family in Banankaro. It is a village in the Kati prefecture in Koulikoro (second administrative region in the Republic of Mali). Originally a primary school teacher in Banankoro, Sibiri C., in order to support his large family, became the owner of a restaurant 5 years ago.   He enjoys a high reputation by the local population and visitors. Sibiri is on his second individual loan with Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner), after the first loan was repaid without difficulty. 

In order to satisfy his ever growing and demanding clientele, Sibiri decided to continue on with the organization.  He plans on using this new loan to purchase 2 tons of rice and a few packages of condiments in wholesale in Bamako (capital city of Mali). He sells his foods (fried rice, rice with peanut sauce, tomato, and green leaves) from his restaurant in the market. It is located along the international route linking Bamako to Abidjan. He completes his sales in cash and on credit, payable on a monthly basis by the officials of the region. 

Sibiri C. expects, with the help of this loan, to earn a monthly income of 70.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to provide for his family's expenses, and to reinvest the remaining portion in his business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for his restaurant.

loans.name: Tenedje

texts.fr:
Madame Tenedje C. est une femme âgée de 58 ans qui vit avec ses 8 enfants, son époux et d’autres parents dans une famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanankoroba, un des villages de la préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro(deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Tenedje C. n’a pas été à l’école pour des raisons sociales. Très tôt elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat vente de produits alimentaires tels les condiments. Tenedje a 20 ans d’expérience dans cette activité de commerce, d’où sa bonne réputation et renommée  à Sanankoroba et environs.
Après avoir correctement remboursés ses six précédents prêts, Tenedje est à son septième prêt individuel, qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter,  différents colis de condiments alimentaires (concentrée de tomate, oignons, sel de cuisine, ails, tomate fraîches, gombo, épices, poivres, poivrons, choux, aubergines, courges, etc), auprès des grossistes à Bamako (capitale du Mali) et des paysans producteurs de Sanankoroba. Elle effectue sa vente à la maison et au  marché de Sanankoroba, en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Madame Tenedje C. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 100.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, aider le mari à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mrs. Tenedje C. is a 58-year old woman who lives with her 8 children, her husband and other parents belonging to this large extended family in Sanankoroba. It is one of the villages in the Kati prefecture in the Region of Koulikoro (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). 

Tenedje C. did not go to school for social reasons. From a very early age she became interested in revenue-generating activities, especially the buying and selling of food products, such as condiments. She has 20 years' experience in the business and her good reputation and fame precede her in Sanankoroba and the surrounding regions.

After having successfully refunded the six past loans, Tenedje is on her seventh individual loan. She plans on using it to purchase a variety of packages of condiments (tomato paste,   onions, salt, garlic, fresh tomatoes, okra, spices, peppers, green peppers, cabbage, eggplants,   squash etc.) from the wholesalers in Bamako (capital city of Mali) and from the producers in   Sanankoroba. 

She carries out retail sales from her house and at the market in Sanankoroba, in cash and credit, to a clientele composed of women and men. 

Mrs. Tenedje C. expects to earn a monthly income of 100.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to help her husband provide for the family's expenses, and to reinvest the remaining portion in the business.

loans.use: To purchase condiments.

loans.name: Bibi

texts.en:
Bibi is a married woman with five children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past twenty years, she has operated a food stall from home; neighbours and passersby are her potential customers. Bibi faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the rainy season the demand for foodstuffs is lower. She hopes to operate a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase stock of beans, wheat flour, cooking oil and rice. She decided to join Yehu because it has not too much legalities.

loans.use: To purchase stock of beans, wheat flour, cooking oil and rice

loans.name: Allakabo Group

texts.fr:
Allakabo est un regroupement de 4 femmes ayant en moyenne 45 ans, 4 enfants et vivant  dans des familles traditionnelles à Keleya, chef lieu d’une commune rurale de la préfecture de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur sixième collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de charbon de bois, bois de chauffe et d’habits et pagnes avec Binta Saganaba.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 10 pièces de pagnes wax et une importante quantité d’habits pour enfants. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché  de Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Elle effectue sa vente au  marché de Keleya et à domicile à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, en détail, au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000 FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
Allakabo is a group of 4 women who are 45 years old on average. They each have 4 children and they live in traditional families in Keleya, an important locale in the rural community belonging to the Bougouni prefecture (third administrative region in the Republic of Mali). 

They are on the sixth group loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) with the goal of satisfying their clients' demands. This group of women sells charcoal, fire wood and clothing and cloth wraps with Binta Saganaba. 

With this loan she will purchase 10 pieces of wax cloth and a large quantity of children’s clothing. She makes her purchases at the large market in Bamako (capital city of Mali) from the wholesalers. She carries out her sales in the market in Keleya and from her house to a clientele mostly made up of women. She sells in retail, taking cash or credit. 

She expects to earn a monthly income of 20.000 FCFA which will be used in part to support her husband in providing for the daily expenses, and a part will be invested in the business.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and fabric.

loans.name: Zoya

texts.en:
Zoya E. is 69 years old and has three children. She graduated from Pedagogical University and worked as a teacher of the Russian language for 33 years. Her colleagues characterize her as a very optimistic and responsible person. Now she is retired and earns her living through breeding cattle. 

Zoya got started in this business 20 years ago when her family needed additional earnings to cover their expenses. Thanks to her persistent and hardworking personality, Zoya managed to make her business successful and today earns about 8,000 KGS monthly. Using the revenue from reselling fattened livestock, she was able to hold daughter’s wedding. 

Zoya plans to use this loan of 100,000 KGS to broaden her business by purchasing more cattle. With the revenue from this investment, Zoya plans further development of her farm. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Balla

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Balla C.  est âgé de 40 ans et vit avec ses 4 enfants et son épouse dans une famille monogame à Dangassa, un des villages de la préfecture  de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Balla C. n’a pas eu la chance  d’aller à l’école. Très tôt  il s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment à l’achat stockage vente de céréales. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son oncle maternel, qui  fut jadis un grand commerçant de céréales. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement           remboursé ses 4 prêts précédents il est à son cinquième individuel  qui servira à acheter, 5 tonnes de céréales (maïs, haricot, mil, fonio) auprès des paysans producteurs de Dangassa et environnants qu’il gardera jusqu’à ce que les produits soient sur le marché. Il vend  essentiellement, sur place en gros à une clientèle constituée de revendeurs venant des grandes villes telles Bamako.
Balla C. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et  être réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Balla C. is 40 years old and he lives with his 4 children and his wife as a monogamous family in Dangassa. It is one of the villages in the Kati prefecture in the region of Koulikoro. 

Balla C. did not have the opportunity to go to school. At a very young age he became interested in revenue-generating activities such as the buying and selling of cereal grains. He learned this trade from his maternal uncle, who was once a great cereal grains merchant.

In order to satisfy his every growing clientele, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). Following the successful repayment of the previous 4 loans, he is now on his fifth individual loan and he will use it to purchase 5 tons of cereal grains (corn, beans, millet, and fonio seed) from the producers in Dangassa and surrounding areas. He will store the grains until the products are sold in the market. He sells primarily in wholesale to a clientele made up of retailers who travel from large cities, such as Bamako. 

Balla C. expects to earn a monthly income of 75.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan and the remaining portion will be reinvested into the business.

loans.use: To purchase cereal grains.

loans.name: Justo

texts.es:
Justo forma parte del banco comunal “La Puerta de la Esperanza” perteneciente a la ciudad de Concepción. Él tiene varios negocios paralelos, ya que todos son esporádicos: vende pescados y mariscos congelados, a otros negocios y clientes particulares. También es carpintero independiente, y además es fabricante de zapatos artesanales. Este último rubro lo aprendió desde hace 17 años, de la familia de su esposa, ya que ellos son zapateros.
Vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos de 15 y 13 años.
Con este préstamo comparará pescados y mariscos congelados.
Su sueño es comprar una casa, ya que vive en un departamento, que aunque es propio, lo limita para instalarse con algún negocio. Por lo que su meta es vender su departamento para comprar una casa e instalar un minimarket o una panadería, ya que tiene dos hermanos que son panaderos y podrían trabajar con él.
A Justo le han sido muy útiles los préstamos de Fondo Esperanza para la mantención de sus negocios, además le es muy grato compartir con sus compañeros de grupo.
Concepción, está asentada en la desembocadura del río Biobío, uno de los más grandes del país, al sur de Chile, en la región del Bíobío. Ha tenido una importante función en nuestra historia, siendo sede de importantes batallas y asentamiento relevante, especialmente durante la Guerra de Arauco, por estar en la frontera con territorio mapuche. Actualmente la ciudad posee un importante desarrollo económico y demográfico, llegando a ser considerada como uno de los núcleos urbanos, demográfico, administrativo, financiero y comercial más relevantes de Chile, después de Santiago y Valparaíso.
texts.en:
Justo is a member of “La Puerta de la Esperanza” Communal Bank in Concepción. He has several parallel businesses but they are all sporadic. He sells frozen fish and shrimp to other businesses and private customers.  He is also an independent carpenter and manufacturer of handmade shoes.  He learned this last trade 17 years ago from his wife’s family who are shoemakers.  

He lives with his wife and two children who are 15 and 13 years old.  He will buy frozen fish and shrimp with this loan.  He lives in an apartment but his dream is to buy a house. Although he owns his apartment, his ability to set up a business there is limited.  So, his goal is to sell his apartment in order to buy a house and set up a minimarket or a bakery since his two brothers are bakers and would be able to work with him.

The loans from Fondo Esperanza have been very useful to Justo in the maintenance his businesses.  In addition, he is very pleased to share with his partners in the group.

Concepción is situated at the mouth of the Biobío River, (one of the largest in the country), to the south of Chile in the Biobío region.  It has had an important role in the country’s history as a place of important settlement and home to major battles, especially during the Arauco War because of its border with Mapuche territory.  Nowadays, the city is experiencing important economic and demographic development and is becoming considered one of the most important demographic, administrative, financial, and commercial urban centers of Chile, after Santiago and Valparaíso.

loans.use: Frozen fish and shrimp

loans.name: Bwavumpologoma Women's Group-Buikwe,lugazi

texts.en:
35 year-old Charles K.  has been operating a medical clinic for the past 10 years in Kiyoola-Lugazi. The clinic has, for the most part, been serving local residents. Charles got training as a medical doctor. On the side, Charles who is happily married with 3 kids, also does some small scale farming. Monthly, this business brings him 300,000Ugandan shillings as profit.  

With this loan, Charles says he is going to purchase more medicines for use at his clinic. Charles belongs to Bwavumpologoma Women's group-Buikwe,Lugazi.

loans.use: The purchase of more medicines for use at his clinic

loans.name: Dramane

texts.fr:
Monsieur Dramane Traoré  est  âgé de 51 ans et vit avec ses 3 enfants et son épouse dans une famille traditionnelle au quartier N’tentou de la ville de Ouelessebougou, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Dramane Traoré n’a pas eu la chance  de réussir à l’école.  Alors il s’initie très rapidement au métier de menuisier. Il a appris cette activité auprès de son oncle. Avec une expérience de….. ans, Monsieur Dramane Traoré jouit d’une grande renommée et est très sollicité à Ouelessebougou et environs.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé les 2 premiers prêts il est à son troisième prêt individuel  qui servira à acheter,  des planches, pointes, colles, vernis, tissus, contreplaqués, matelas, etc, auprès des grossistes de la place. Il fabrique des  meubles, armoires, chaises, souvent sur commande et effectue sa vente à une clientèle diverse et variée, au comptant et quelques fois à crédit.
Dramane espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et  être réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Dramane Traore is 51 years old and he lives with his 3 children and his wife in a traditional family in the quarter of N'Tentou of the city of Ouelessebougou. It is located in the Kati prefecture in the Koulikoro region. 

Dramane Traore did not have the opportunity to attend school, so he set out very quickly in the carpentry trade.  He learned the trade from this uncle. Given his several years' experience in the field, Mr. Dramane Traore enjoys a high reputation and is highly solicited in Ouelessebougou and the environs. 

IN order to satisfy his ever growing clientele, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). Following the successful repayment of the first 2 loans, he is now on his third individual loan. He will use it to purchase planks of wood, clamps, glue, varnish, fabrics, plywood, cushioning materials, etc. from the wholesalers in the area. He makes furniture, armoires, and chairs, often taking orders. He sells to a diverse and varied clientele, completing his sales in cash and sometimes on credit. 

Dramane expects to earn a monthly loan of 40.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan and to reinvest the remaining portion into his business.

loans.use: To purchase carpentry materials.

loans.name: Fanta

texts.fr:
Madame Fanta K.  est âgée de 45 ans et vit avec ses 6 enfants et son époux dans une famille monogame à Dangassa, un des villages de la préfecture  de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Fanta K. est une femme analphabète qui s’est vite initiée aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment  à l’achat stockage vente de céréales. Elle est très appréciée à Dangassa et environs.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, elle décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement           remboursé ses 2 prêts précédents, elle est à son troisième  prêt individuel  qui servira à acheter,  3,5 tonnes de céréales (maïs, arachide et sésame) auprès des  producteurs. Elle vend  essentiellement en gros à une clientèle constituée de revendeurs de Ouelessebougou et Bamako. 
Fanta K. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et  être réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fanta K. is 45 years old and she lives with her 6 children and her husband as a monogamous family in Dangassa. It is a village in the Kati prefecture in the region of Koulikoro. 

Fanta K. is illiterate and very early on she started her revenue-generating activities, especially the purchase and storage of cereal grains. She is well liked in Dangassa and the surrounding areas. 

In order to satisfy her ever growing clientele she decided to join Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). Following the successful repayment of 2 previous loans, she is now on her third individual loan. She will use it to purchase 3.5 tons of cereal grains (corn, peanuts and sesame seeds) from the producers. She sells primarily in wholesale to a clientele made up of retailers in Ouelessebougou and Bamako. 

Fanta K. expects to earn a monthly income of 75.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan and the remaining portion will be invest back into the business.

loans.use: To purchase cereal grains.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Bolot

texts.en:
Bolot A. is a 48-year-old farmer who lives in Sarybulak village, in north Kyrgyzstan. He is married and has four children. Bolot has been engaged in animal breeding for 20 years. As a very purposeful and positive person, Bolot has worked hard to support his family and achieved success – today his farm amounts to three milch cows, one heifer and seven sheep. Using his starting capital of only 3,000 KGS, he managed to earn about 10,000 KGS in a month through selling milk to the local dairy plant. 

Now Bolot plans to use this loan of  75,000 KGS to buy one milch cow and help his wife in broadening her grocery business by purchasing more goods to resell. In the future, Bolot plans to build a huge barn for his cattle.

Bai Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target especially vulnerable people. Bai Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: to purchase a milch cow

loans.name: Halimah

texts.en:
Halimah is a married woman with seven children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a charcoal selling business for the past six years, selling from home to her neighbours. In addition she also sells firewood makes up her other source of income. Halimah faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the rainy season the availability of products for sale is low. She hopes to establish a retail shop in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal and firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu because it has not too many legal requirements.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal and firewood for resale

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mamadou C.  est âgé de 28 ans et vit avec son enfant, d’autres parents et son épouse dans une famille traditionnelle à Dangassa, un des villages de la préfecture  de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Mamadou  C. n’a pas eu la chance  d’aller à l’école, alors très tôt  il s’intéressa à plusieurs activités génératrices de revenus tels la couture et  le commerce. Monsieur Mamadou C. est  de nos jours un tailleur couturier très connu et apprécié dans le village de Dangassa et environs.  En plus de cette  prestation de service, il fait également  l’achat stockage vente des céréales. Il a appris cette activité  de couture auprès d’un de ses cousins. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse car diversifiée, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Il est à son premier prêt  qui servira à acheter,  une importante quantité de divers matériels de couture (fil de couture, de broderie, aiguilles etc.) et 3 tonnes de céréales (maïs et fonio) auprès des paysans producteurs des villages environnants. Il vend  essentiellement en gros à une clientèle constituée de revendeurs venant des grandes villes telles Bamako et Ségou. Mamadou C. fait ses prestations dans son atelier de couture sis à Dangassa. Il a une clientèle diverse et variée.
Mamadou C. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 100.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et  être réinvestir le reste dans les activités. 
Il ambitionne devenir un grossiste en stockage commercialisation à Dangassa.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou C. is 28 years old and he lives with his child, with other parents and with his wife in a traditional family in Dangassa. It is a village in the Kati prefecture in the region of Koulikoro. 

Mamadou C. did not have the opportunity to attend school, so at a very early age he became interested in many revenue-generating activities, such as sewing and commerce. Mr. Mamadou C. is a very well known and very well liked tailor in the village of Dangassa and the surrounding regions. In addition to this trade he is also involved in the buying and selling of cereal grains. He learned to be a tailor from his cousins. 

In order to satisfy his ever growing and diversified clientele, he decided to join Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). 

This is his first loan and it will help him buy a large quantity of a variety of sewing  materials (threads, laces, needles etc.) and 3 tons of cereal grains (corn and fonio seeds) from  the producers in the surrounding villages. He sells primarily in wholesale to a clientele made up of retailers who travel from the large cities of Bamako and Segou. Mamadou C. carries out his trade in Dangassa. He has a clientele which is diversified and varied. 

Mamadou C. expects to earn a monthly income of 100.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan and to reinvest the remaining portion into this business.

He endeavors to become a wholesaler in Dangassa.

loans.use: To purchase sewing supplies and cereal grains.

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou D.  est âgée de 44 ans et vit avec ses 4 enfants, ses coépouses et son époux dans une famille traditionnelle élargie à Dangassa, un des villages de la préfecture  de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Oumou D. n’est pas partie à l’école pour des raisons sociales. Très tôt  elle s’intéressa aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment aux agrégats de construction sable, gravier, moellon, dalles, etc. Elle a appris cette activité (qui reste très dominée par les hommes au Mali) auprès de son  grand frère, qui est un grand commerçant de matériels de construction. 
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance, elle décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso. Après avoir correctement remboursé son premier prêt elle est à son deuxième individuel  qui servira à acheter, 50 m3 de sables et 10 m3 de gravier auprès des GIE qui font les extractions de ces matériaux au fleuve. Elle vend  essentiellement en gros à une clientèle constituée d’entrepreneurs de Ouelessebougou et Bamako. Elle  reçoit  souvent des  commandes  de fournitures de certaines entreprises en B.T.P. en sables, graviers etc.
Oumou D. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 90.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt et  être réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Oumou D. is 44 years old and she lives with her 4 children, her co-wives, and her husband in a traditional extended family in Dangassa. It is a village in the Kati prefecture in the region of Koulikoro. 

Oumou D. did not attend school for social reasons. From a very early age she became interested in revenue generating activities including construction materials such as sand, gravel, rubble, cement slabs, etc. she learned the business (which is highly dominated by men in Mali) from her eldest brother who is a great merchant of construction materials. 

IN order to satisfy an ever growing clientele, she decided to join Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). Having successfully repaid her first loan, she is now on her second individual loan.  She will use it to purchase 50 cubic meters of sand, 10 cubic meters of gravel from GIE who extract the materials from the river. She sells essentially in wholesale to a clientele made up of retailers in Ouelessebougou and Bamako. She often receives orders for supplies from certain companies in B.T.P. including sand, gravel, etc.

OUmou D. expects to earn a monthly income of 90.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan and to reinvest the remaining portion in her business.

loans.use: To purchase sand and gravel.

loans.name: Salif

texts.fr:
Monsieur Salif Dembélé  est un homme  qui est âgé de 51 ans et qui vit avec ses 12 enfants et son épouse dans une famille monogame dans la ville de Sélingué, préfecture de Yanfolila,  Région de Sikasso.
Afin de s’insérer dans la vie économique, Salif,  qui entreprena plusieurs activités mais sans succès finit par opter pour le stockage commercialement de céréales.  
Nanti  de 6  années d’expériences dans le domaine, il est très sollicité.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle qui ne cesse d’accroître, Salif décide d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.  
Salif  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 3 tonnes de riz  et 2 tonnes de maïs  auprès des paysans producteurs de Sélingué et environs qu’il stockera au  moins quelques mois. Il effectue sa vente au marché de Dalabala et Bamako, en gros et en détail, au comptant et rarement à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Salif espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 50.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Salif Dembele is a 51-year old man who lives with his 12 children and his wife in a monogamous family in the city of Selingue. It is located in the prefecture of Yanfolila in the region of Sikasso. 

In order to integrate himself into the economy, Salif, who took on several business activities without success, finally decided to concentrate in the sale of cereal grains. 

With the benefit of 6 years' experience in the field, he is highly solicited. 

In order to satisfy an ever growing clientele, Salif decided to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner), with which he is on his first individual loan. 

Salif plans on using his loan to purchase 3 tons of rice and 2 tons of corn from the producers in Selingue and the surrounding regions. He will store the products for at least one month. He makes his sales in the market in Dalabala and Bamako in wholesale and retail, completing the sale in cash and occasionally on credit. His clientele is made up of women and men. 

Salif expects to earn a monthly income of 50.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to provide his family's expenses, and to invest the remaining portion in his business.

loans.use: To purchase cereal grains.

loans.name: Anton

texts.en:
Anton K. is young salesman of DVD- discs at the market of Karakol town, which is in the north-east of Kyrgyzstan. His small family consists of his mother and younger sister. Anton has had to earn his living from childhood, when his father left the family. When he entered the faculty of journalism of the National University, he paid for his education by himself, without any help. He earned the money in the summers doing any work he could find – courier, forwarder, helper to the water transport instructor, and correspondent. After graduating from the University, Anton decided to start selling DVDs, which became his family business. With the support of his mother, Anton bought a small shop at the central market of Karakol. With the initial capital of 10,000 KGS, he managed to raise floating capital of 20,000 KGS. Now, in order to develop his business, Anton applies for a loan of 52,000 KGS to broaden his assortment of goods. With the revenues, he plans to provide his shop, which made of steel, with heat insulation. Also, Anton saves up money for a good education for his younger sister, which will allow her have a prosperous future. 

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors. 
_____________________________________________________________________

loans.use: to broaden his inventory

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 21-year-old single man from Lebanon living with his parents and two siblings. He opened a clothing store in 2008 and started to offer his customers different models and styles. He is very optimistic and hopes to expand his business in the near future. 

Today, he is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to increase his shop’s inventory so he can provide his customers with a wide variety of clothes and attract more customers.

loans.use: to increase his shop’s inventory

loans.name: Sadijatu

texts.en: This is 35-year-old Sadijatu. She is married and has three children, ages 14, 9, and 8. She has one additional dependent. In 2004, Sadijatu established her drinks and clothing business. Working 6 days a week and 13 hours a day, she earns about Le 300,000 every month. She would like a loan in the amount of Le 3,000,000 in order to buy more cotton fabrics. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 500,000. In the future, Sadijatu plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more cotton fabrics

loans.name: Sounkoura

texts.fr:
Madame Sounkoura Traoré  est une célibataire âgée de 44 ans, sans enfant qui vit dans une famille nucléaire dans le village de Sanankoroba, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Afin de s’insérer dans la vie économique, Sounkoura,  qui est enseignante de formation entreprena plusieurs activités mais finit par apprendre auprès de sa  tante, le commerce d’articles divers tels les pagnes fancy, wax et la fabrication et vente d’encens. Elle a cinq ans d’expériences dans le domaine, elle est très sollicitée.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, Sounkoura décide d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.
Sounkoura compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, une grande quantité de matières premières entrant dans la fabrication de l’encens. EIle effectue sa vente à domicile et  au marché de Sanankoroba, au comptant et rarement à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Sounkoura espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75.000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt, aider son époux à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mrs. Soukoura Traore is a single woman who is 44 years of age. She doesn't have children and she lives in a nuclear family in the village of Sanankoroba. It is located in the Kati prefecture, in the region of Koulikoro. 

IN order to integrate him into the economy, Soukoura, who is a teacher by trade, took on a several business activities but finally decided to learn from her aunt the business of selling merchandise, including printed fabrics, wax cloth and the production and sale of incense. She has 5 years' experience in the field and she is highly solicited. 

While in search for additional financial resources, Soukoura decided to join the credit program at the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). 

Soukoura plans on using her loan to purchase a large quantity of materials she needs to make incense. She makes her sales from her house and at the market in Sanankoroba, completing the sales in cash and occasionally on credit. Her clientele is made up of women and men. 

Soukoura expects to earn a monthly income of 75.000 FCFA which will be used to repay this loan, to help her husband provide for the family's expenses, and to reinvest the remaining portion into the business.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make incense.

loans.name: Mebakari

texts.en:
Mebakari is a married woman with two children; one attends school while the other one is still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past seven years, she has been selling khangas (Kikoi, or traditional African cloth) from home to her neighbors, especially women. Mebakari faces a major challenge of bad debts from those who purchase goods on credit and fail to pay her. She hopes to establish a cereal shop in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings loan, she wants to purchase stock of khangas (traditional African cloth) for resale. She decided to join Yehu because it has fewer legalities.

loans.use: To purchase stock of khangas (Kikoi, or traditional African cloth) for resale.

loans.name: Kalabirwamu Development Group-Lugazi

texts.en: N. Christine, 35, with hand raised, has sold charcoal for the past ten years in Kalabirwamu-Lugazi. It is a business the happily married mother of six has relied on to support herself and her family financially. She says she began this business with savings from her farming business. Christine also sells fish and says, with this loan, she is going to buy more bags of charcoal to resell.

loans.use: To purchase bags of charcoal to resell

loans.name: Madou

texts.fr:
Monsieur  MADOU S. est un homme  qui est âgé de  40 ans et qui vit avec ses 3 enfants et son épouse dans une famille monogame à N’tentou, dans la ville de Ouelessebougou, préfecture de Kati,  Région de Koulikoro.
Afin de s’insérer dans la vie économique, MADOU S., qui n’a pas eu la chance  de réussir à l’école, s’est vite initié aux activités de stockage commercialement des céréales et des produits de cueillettes tels le néré, les noix d’acajou et  le tamarin.  
Nanti  7 années d’expériences dans le domaine, il est très sollicité.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, MADOU décide d’adhérer au programme crédit de l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son  septième prêt individuel.
MADOU  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 2 tonnes de maïs, 1 tonne  d’arachide et 5 sacs de tamarin, auprès des paysans producteurs de Tièlé et de Ouelessebougou qu’il stockera pendant au moins 2 mois. Il effectue sa vente  au marché de Ouelesseboubou, au comptant et rarement à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
MADOU S. espère réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 100.000 FCFA qui   sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt,  subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et réinvestir le reste dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Madou S. is a 40-year-old man who lives with his wife and their three children in a monogamous family in N'Tentou, in the town of Ouelessebougou, prefecture of Kati, Koulikoro region. 

Madou S. did not have the opportunity to pursue extensive studies. In order to enter the work force, he soon learned the business of commercial storage of grain and gathered fruits such as nere seeds, cashew nuts and tamarind. With seven years of experience in this activity, he is in high demand.

In his search for complementary financing, Madou turned to the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution and is now on his seventh individual loan. 

Madou plans to use his loan to buy two tons of corn, one ton of peanuts and five sacks of tamarind from local producers in Tièlé and Ouelessebougou. The merchandise will be stored for at least two months. He conducts his sales at the Ouelesseboubou market for cash, rarely on credit, to a customer base consisting of both men and women. 

Madou S. hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 100,000 FCFA which will be used to repay the loan and cover family expenses, the remainder to be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: To purchase grain

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice C. is a married lady of 48 who resides in Kapsabet town. She is blessed with three children between 24 and 14. Alice owns a shop in Cheplengu trading centre and has been in this business for eight years.  

Her monthly profit is Ksh. 3,000 and she normally saves this amount. Alice has borrowed a loan of Kshs. 10,000 from KADET LTD.It is her first loan with which she intends to purchase more stock for her shop, such as tea, cooking oil, and salt. 

Her hope and dream is to own a wholesale shop in future.

loans.use: To purchase business stock

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. She has operated a matatu (motor vehicle) business for the past seven years; town dwellers are her potential customers. In addition to that, she also operates a retail shop and charcoal-selling business that contributes to her other source of income. Caroline faces a major challenge of seasonality. During rush hours, the demand for transportation is high compared to the normal hours of the day. She hopes to purchase a bus for transport in the future. With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase a new tire to repair her matatu (motor vehicle). She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase a new tire to repair her matatu (motor vehicle)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret O. is 48 years old from Nyamasaria area in the outskirts of Kisumu town. She is a widow and has six children to care for.

Margaret has a business selling second hand clothes. She is applying for her second loan from KADET LTD after successfully completing the first one. She needs money to buy more clothes to add to her stock. Her monthly income is KES 5,000 and she intends to use the profits to pay school fees for her children.

Her desire is to find a stable place for her business and see it expand.

loans.use: Buy more clothes to add to her stock

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with three children, one of whom attends school while the others already graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a food stall business for the past two years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. In addition, she owns a real-estate agency that contributes to her other source of income. Mwanakombo faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. During the rainy season, the business is very low. She hopes to establish a hardware shop in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase stock of beans, rice and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu because it has no legal requirements.

loans.use: To purchase stock of beans, rice and wheat flour

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret N. is 47 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has six children, none of whom are currently in school. Margret has a small shop, which she has run for less than one year. Margret enjoys sitting in her shop.
To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 2,500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase sugar and soap for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Margret hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.

loans.use: To purchase sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 38-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents and one sibling. He's owned an air conditioning products and appliances store for 22 years. He is the only income source for the family. He obtained his first Kiva loan and was a very good client with punctual payments.

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1700 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase new tools and equipment so he can proceed with his work properly.

loans.use: To purchase new tools and equipment

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is 37 years old and he is still married with one child who is four years old. He makes a living by selling a variety of goods and food in his shop including biscuits, toilet paper, water, sugar, soap and soft drinks. Emmanuel has been in this business for about five years and the hours of his business are from 6am to 7pm every day.

Emmanuel has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company so that he can expand his business by purchasing a large quantity of foodstuffs such as beans, rice, sugar, salt, etc. With these additional foodstuffs for sale, Emmanuel hopes that the number of customers will increase as well as his profits. These profits will be used to reinvest further and to build a secure future for his family.

loans.use: To buy a large quantity of foodstuffs and goods

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia N. is 28 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has no children. Sylvia has a small shop, which she has run for less than one year. Sylvia likes meeting her customers at the shop.       
To help expand her business, Sylvia has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase sugar and soap for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Sylvia hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to own a plot of land.

loans.use: To purchase sugar and soap for resale

loans.name: Jane Rongoe

texts.en:
Jane is a single lady, 32 years old, who lives in the Ololchani area in Kilgoris. 

Jane Rongoe is a farmer and has been in this business for the past four years. She mainly plants beans and is applying for her sixth loan from KADET LTD to enable her to buy bean seedlings to plant. Her monthly income is Kes 40,000, which she intends to invest back into the business.

Her hope is to see her business expand.

loans.use: To buy bean seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 27-year-old single man from Lebanon. He lives with his parents. He's owned an electronics and mobile shop since 2009. He is the only income source for his family. He did obtained four Kiva loans and is very satisfied with the results.

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1200 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase additional electronic products so he can increase his sales and income.

loans.use: To purchase additional electronic products

loans.name: Shiella

texts.en:
Shella N. is from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. She is 23 years old. She grows rice for a living. It is her hope to increase her harvest so that she could provide for her family’s needs and improve their living conditions.

Receiving a loan from CEVI will help her buy seeds and fertilizers for her farm. She also would like to venture into other businesses to augment her income. The profit that she earns from her farm will also go to her savings.

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance N. is 50 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is single and has three children, none of whom are currently in school. Constance has a cosmetics shop business, which she has run for five years. She also has a second business running a clothes boutique.
To help expand her business, Constance has requested a loan of 2,500,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase cosmetics and clothes for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Constance hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 50 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, none of whom are currently in school. Mary has a small pharmacy business selling medicines, which she has run for over ten years.
To help expand her business, Mary has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from Kiva partner, BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more medicines for resale. With the help of her loan from BRAC, Mary hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, she hopes to expand her business further.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase more bananas to roast and later resell

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. She has operated a charcoal-selling business for the past five years, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. Mary faces a major challenge of transportation and seasonality. During the rainy season, the availability of charcoal is limited. She hopes to purchase a matatu (a motor vehicle) for transportation in the future. With the 80,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for resale and building materials to finish her construction. She decided to work with Yehu because it does not require legal attachments.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for resale and building materials to finish her construction

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food for her store

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
Daniel, tiene 41 años de edad, reside en Santa Elena, departamento de Usulután, donde vive con su esposa y tres hijos de 7, 5 y un año de edad, solamente él trabaja y se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería, él comenzó desde muy pequeño ayudándole a su padre en las actividades agropecuarias, hoy en día realiza este trabajo para ayudar a su familia y darle el sustento diario, ya que es la única fuente de ingreso que tienen.
Por el momento Daniel tiene planes de comprarse ganado, para lo cual solicita un préstamo, pues no tiene lo suficiente en dinero para cubrir los gastos, esta inversión le ayudara a crecer en el negocio teniendo más reces en sus terrenos.
Uno de sus sueños es convertirse en un ganadero con un gran número de ganado, obteniendo mayor reconocimiento con los ganaderos de la zona; Con su familia pues quiere mejorar su condición económica y darle lo mejor a sus hijos empezando con los estudios.
texts.en:
Daniel, age 41, lives in Santa Elena in the Usulután department.  He lives with his wife and three children, ages 7, 5, and 1.  He is the only one that works.  He is a farmer and he raises cattle.  He started when he was very young by helping his father with the agricultural work.  

He does this work now in order to help his family and to feed them.  It is the only source of income that they have.  Daniel now plans to buy livestock.  That is why he is requesting a loan.  He does not have enough money to cover the expenses.  This investment will help him grow his business by having more cattle on his land.

One of his dreams is to become a rancher with a lot of cattle, and he will then become more well-known to the ranchers in the area.  For his family, he wants to improve its financial condition and to give his children the best, starting with their education.

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sacks of beans, rice, wheat flour, cooking oil and charcoal for cooking

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: This is 48 year-old Ibrahim K.. He is married, and has 5 children ages 3, 5, 8, 12 and 14. In 1981, Ibrahim established his used clothes and bags business. He began his business because he wanted to earn a profit to support his family. Working six days a week and seven hours a day, he earns about Le 540,000 every month. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000 in order to increase stock for his business. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 400,000. In the future, Ibrahim plans to educate his children, improve his sales stall and build a house. He is very serious and dedicated and thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional assorted used items.

loans.name: Barnard

texts.en:
Barnard O. is 38 years old and lives in the town of Njeru in the Jinja region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. Bernard has a small retail shop business, which he has run for less than one year. He has a second business offering rental houses.
To help expand his business, Bernard has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase materials to complete work on his rental houses. With the help of his loan from BRAC, Bernard hopes to generate greater profits and pay school fees. In the future, he hopes to own another business.

loans.use: To purchase materials to complete work on his rental houses

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en: This is 49 year-old Hawa M.. She is married and has 4 children ages 6, 9, 12 and 15. She has two additional dependents who live with her because they help with her business. In 2000, Hawa established her drinks business where she sells soft drinks and safe drinking water. She began her business because she wanted to help her husband. Working six days a week and six hours a day, she earns about Le 350,000 every month from this business. Hawa has already received and successfully repaid one loan, and now would like a second loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 500,000. In the future, Hawa plans to open a bigger shop and hire a sales person. She is very determined.

loans.use: Buy more drinks for her shop.

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida is a married woman with two children, both of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For over thirty years, she has operated a water point-selling business from home, selling to her neighbours. In addition, she also sells food items, which brings in another source of income. Saida faces a major challenge of seasonality. During the rainy season the demand for water is minimal. She hopes to operate a retail shop in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase stock of potatoes, wheat flour, oil and charcoal. She decided to join Yehu because of its simple loaning procedures.

loans.use: To purchase stock of potatoes, wheat flour, cooking oil and charcoal.

loans.name: Matanu

texts.en: Matanu M. is a married lady.  Her husband is a driver, and they have four children, aged between twenty-two years old and eight years old. Her business is located at Mukuru kwa Njenga in Nairobi, and she is served by the Kitengela branch. She owns a grocery store in which she sells such items as kale, bananas and tomatoes. She has been in this business for the last five years. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge  is that there are so many people doing the same kind of business in the area. Customers are not loyal, as they are spoilt for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 60,000 to buy more kale, tomatoes and other vegetables to grow her business and meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to be a wholesaler in future and also to diversify into the salon business. She describes herself as aggressive and business-minded.

loans.use: Kale, Tomatoes

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more milk, sugar, soft drinks, powder, toothbrushes, toothpaste, shoe polish, sardines, body lotion etc

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of flour, sugar, oil, yeast, etc

loans.name: Rodah

texts.en:
Rodah O. is fifty eight years old, married and has four children who are between the ages  twenty four  and thirty five years old.  Her business is located at Shikoti market in Kakamega and is well known by its name Shama medical clinic.  

Kakamega is the region in Kenya known for production of sugar cane and is commonly referred as the sugar belt region.  She owns a clinic in which she has been providing treatment as well as selling drugs to the local people, school children and teachers.  She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is low purchasing power by the people in the area.  However she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 30,000 KES to buy a weighing scale and drugs to treat as many diseases as possible.  She hopes to grow her business into a nursing home in the future.  She describes herself as visionary, competent and kind.

loans.use: To purchase weighing scale and drugs to treat as many diseases as possible.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has operated a firewood-selling business for the past six months, selling from home to her neighbors. Salama faces a major challenge in the high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to establish a retail shop in the future.

With the 30,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase a bundle of firewood for resale. She decided to join Yehu because of its simplicity to join.

loans.use: To purchase a bundle of firewood for resale

loans.name: Wulamatu

texts.en:
This is 30-year-old Wulamatu K.. She is married and has two children, ages 6 and 12 years. In 2008, Wulamatu established her business; she sells items such as bedspreads and trousers. She began her business because she wanted to help her husband. Working six days a week and six hours a day, she earns about 400,000 Sierra Leone leones (Le) every month. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,000,000 and hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Wulamatu plans to buy stock from the neighboring country of Guinea. She would also like to educate her children to the university level. Wulamatu is very determined.

loans.use: Improve the stock of her business

loans.name: Elida Del Carmen

texts.es:
Doña Elida, es una señora de 64 años de edad, vive con su hija y un nieto en Santa Elena, departamento de Usulután, ella se dedica a una granja de pollos, los cuales los vende cada 6 semanas pero ya lavados, listos para cocinar, este negocio comenzó por iniciativa propia, no tiene horario fijo de trabajo.
Actualmente está solicitando un préstamo para la compra de gallinas, alimento, además quiere comprar ropa para comenzar a vender también ropa, este préstamo le permitirá crecer y contar con lo necesario para alimentar a las gallinas, también atenderá una nueva actividad económica de la que espera obtener ganancias adicionales para su familia.
Ella quiere crecer, que su granja sea más amplia, aumentar su clientela, desarrollarse en el comercio y atender la demanda de su clientela, también contribuir a mejorar la condición económica de su familia.
texts.en:
Elida is a 64 year-old lady who lives with her daughter and a grandchild in Santa Elena, in Usulután department.  Elida has a chicken farm.  She sells her chickens every 6 weeks, washed and ready to cook.  She started this business on her own initiative.  She does not work fixed hours in her business.

Currently, Elida is requesting a loan to buy chickens and feed.  She also wants to buy clothes so that she can start selling clothes.  This loan will allow her to grow her business and to have available what she needs to feed her chickens.  She will also set up a new business activity from which she hopes to make additional income for her family.

Elida would like to grow in her business, for her farm to become bigger, to increase her number of customers, to make progress in her business and to meet her customer demand.  She would also like to contribute to improving her family's financial situation.

loans.use: To buy chickens, concentrated chicken feed and clothes

loans.name: Marie

texts.en:
This is 35-year-old Marie T.. She is married and has two children, ages 8 and 12. In 2009, Marie established her cooking-utensils business. She began her business because she wanted to help her husband. Working six days a week and six hours a day, she earns about 400,000 Sierra Leone leones (Le) every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000 in order to improve herself and her family. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, Marie T. plans to educate her children and buy land. She is very determined to open a store to sell wholesale to other traders. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To add more stock to her stall

loans.name: Mwanatumu

texts.en:
Mwanatumu is a married woman with five children, two of whom attend school while the others have graduated.  She owns a house that has electricity and piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

She has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby.  Mwanatumu faces a major challenge of seasonality and competition from other charcoal sellers in her business.  She hopes to be self reliant in her business in the future.

With the 60,000 KES she wants to purchase twenty sacks of charcoal and construction materials to renovate two rooms for rental.  She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase twenty sacks of charcoal and construction materials to renovate two rooms for rental.

loans.name: Apolinaria

texts.en:
Apolinaria is a married woman who lives in Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu.  She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: Guitar Making, Sari-sari (general) store and food vending businesses.  Her husband Gregorio A., who is 51 years old years old, works as a Guitar Maker to earn his living. They have 8 children who are 17 to 30 years old - 4 of them have their own family, 3 employed children to help the family and 1 is currently going to school.  

Apolinaria joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2006 because she aspired for something better for her family.  With the help of her past 10 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Apolinaria has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow.  Her previous loan of 10,000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 34,000 PHP, thus increasing the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 11th cycle loan, she is borrowing 13,000 PHP which she intends to use as more funds for her business operations so that she could continue to save up for the future, education of her child and for home repairs.  

Apolinaria is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams.  

About NWTF:  

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  

Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.
"

loans.use: Funds for her business operations.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en: Susana is a 50-year-old widow who supports her family by operating two business ventures: hog fattening and banana selling. She lives in Victorias City, Negros Occidental.
